excerpt: Learn more about This Week’s Weird and Wonderful: Valentine’s Day Edition, 2025 on Bring a Trailer, the home of the best vintage and classic cars online.
text: It’s getting late on Valentine’s Day of 2025, and that means it’s time to check in with a very special edition of the Weekly Weird and Wonderful! We tried our best to contain it today, and we just couldn’t—you’ll notice several group picks from among the 933 auctions that closed in the last week, and the 814 that are currently live on the site. This is by no means a comprehensive list. There’s certainly much more to be seen on the live auctions page, but here are some of the listings that stood out to us this week. 1. 1986 Porsche 962C Our first featured listing came to us from the land of heart-shaped hot tubs—the Pocono Mountain region in Pennsylvania. It’s a Porsche-built 962C that was delivered to Trust Racing in Japan, and campaigned for three years before being rebuilt and sold to Bernie Ecclestone. There was a lot to love in this auction, from the big names in the ownership history to the learned discussions on the finer points of Porsche racing engine development to the surprisingly ample headroom in the cockpit. Seller extraordinaire Bill_Noon was the MC in the comments section, and his personal stories and detailed descriptions of the car’s post-Group C history could be bound in their own volume. For the recent winner, @internetpros, here’s the late Jim Pace giving us a tutorial on how to drive a 962 around Daytona—presumably something you’re going to want to do as soon as is humanly possible. 2. 51-Years-Owned 1955 BMW 502 Cabriolet by Baur Our friends in Europe are bringing the love with another V8-powered postwar BMW roadster. Let’s hope we can adhere to our new one-per-week quota. This car has been with its current owner for 51 years(!), and as one of 57 Bauer cabriolet conversions is numerically rarer than last week’s 1959 BMW 507 Series II, with which it shares a 3.2-liter aluminum V8. We can’t decide if we think it looks better with the top up or down, and those deeply swept fenderlines give any contemporary Jaguar a run for its money. 3. Maserati A6GCS Monofaro Re-Creation This Pur Sang-built Maserati A6GCS “Monofaro” not only hails from Fangio’s homeland of Argentina, but in fact was built around a 2.0L SOHC inline-six that was reportedly removed from a Fangio-raced F2 car in the late 1940s. EU Local Partner Colombo and Company is representing the car for the owner, who commissioned its construction in 2017. We are still holding our breath for a driving video, but in the meantime please enjoy this footage from Duke Video of Fangio doing his thing in a 1950s Maserati F1 car at Monza. 4. Trio of Nissan Motorsports Vehicles Seller vance911 has tapped into a deep vein of Nissan racers. Several of the vehicles have been displayed in the Nissan Heritage Collection at the Lane Motor Museum in Nashville, Tennessee. First up is a Bob Sharp SCCA racing chassis in need of a drivetrain and some other bits. Brooklyn67 tells a heartwarming story of his experience with the car as a young lad: I knew this car up close and personal, in high school! I bought my first car, a 280z, from Bob Sharp (Racing) at his Ferrari and race shop in Bethel, CT, in 1982/83. [Wilton, CT, is where his Nissan dealership was.] The Ferrari dealership and race shop looked like a series of broken down brown wooden shacks…and what initially caught my eye was a black BB512, next to the silver 280z that I ended up buying…sitting outside. I knew nothing about mechanics back then, except for working on my moped, but I wanted to modify my Z. Besides buying the big shop manual and Fred Puhn’s “How to make your car handle” (both of which I still have), I wandered into the race shop that was right next to the tiny performance parts office, and met Stu (I think that was his name), who was the shop manager. I was then immediately blown away by seeing this spaceship that was THIS car, the 300zx that Newman raced. Stu let me spend so much time in this jam-packed shop on many days that I would come down there to better understand how the car worked. Seeing this car and being around the Bob Sharp race shop intensified my learning and ability to work on and modify my Z. If it wasn’t for this experience, spending hours looking at this car in the shop (as well as Newman’s race videos), I’m not sure I would have ended up racing (cars and mostly motorcycles) 10-15 years later. I’m incredibly envious of whomever wins this incredible piece of history (in general and in my race education)… GLWTA! Next is a former pace car from Road America. Z31hunter notes that this is an early-production example of the Z31 chassis, and it has accumulated 18k miles and has served as the safety car for vintage Datsun and Nissan events. The seller describes the last of the trio thusly: Nissan built three D21 land speed trucks. One was prepped for racing and beat the world land speed record at Bonneville Flats for four-cylinder trucks at 142mph; while the other two trucks were sent to each coast to help market/sell the new D21 truck. This D21 is the only survivor of the three and was displayed at the Nissan Heritage Museum in Nashville, TN for many years. It’s currently titled for street use in Georgia and might be pretty driveable, so long as you don’t need sounds deadening or a passenger seat. 5. Euro 1964 Citroen Ami 6 and 1975 Citroen Mehari This is, in fact, the Ami Berline formerly belonging to @mbaum and @Bronson, a German-market example that made its way through the UK, Canada, and finally the US in 2020. As if this strikingly-styled version of the 2CV were not enough, seller @Wob also has a Citroen Mehari live on the site. This plastic-paneled runabout shares its 602cc engine with the Ami. 6. c.1903 American LaFrance Metropolitan Steam Fire Engine Well, well, well—another tank from @Wob. This one happens to be a steam boiler tank providing power to a two-piston pumper apparatus. If you’re thinking to yourself “who needs/has a place to put a horse-drawn steam pumper wagon,” the bidding is currently at $47k with six days left and there are folks with strong opinions about early 20th-century firefighting equipment asking important questions in the comments section. 7. 1977 Chevrolet Opala 4100 De Luxo Coupe 4-Speed It’s not a Brazilian Chevy Nova—this is a German Opel Rekord chassis wearing Brazilian styling. We never could have had this in-period, but we always love seeing how South American markets adapted the platforms that they were given by the rest of the world. This one is currently in Texas, so you won’t have to get it across the Darién Gap. 8. Gasser-Style Austin A40 Devon Apparently Austin “Gassers” are a thing, and they were apparently the preferred platform of drag racer Junior Thompson back in the 1960s. This little sedan has a built 350 with Offy components and a wheelbase shorter than that of a classic Austin Mini. 9. Ex–Michael Andretti Ralt RT5 Formula Super Vee This is the car in which Michael Andretti won his first overall auto racing championship in 1982. Formula Vee had upped its game by the early ’80s, adding the winged Formula Super Vee series and replacing the old swing axles and air-cooled flat-fours with double wishbones and inboard shocks as well as water-cooled VW Scirocco engines, tuned by Brabham in this example. Andretti was just 20 years old when he drove this FSV, on his way to a Hall of Fame career that included a 1991 CART championship. 1:1 Scale Bentley Continental GT Wooden Display Model We are speechless, so we’ll hand the mic to @CraZ8: Honorable Mention: Modified 1939 American Bantam Roadster If an Austin Seven isn’t weird enough for you, try this 1939 Bantam roadster—an American license-built variant. This car came out of the IMS Museum collection in 2020, and is now being represented by the seller in snowy Clarence, New York. Honorable Mention: Lotus 23B Driving this at Goodwood or the Monterey Historics must be sheer bliss. Honorable Mention: Euro 1995 BMW 328i Touring 5-Speed Go big or go home, people. We do dig the red Vaders. That’s all we’ve got for this week, but we’d love to hear what caught your eye! Let us know in the comments.

We are speechless, so we’ll hand the mic to @CraZ8:

Honorable Mention: Modified 1939 American Bantam Roadster
